content.question: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Piperidine, <math alttext="C 5 H 10 N H" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>10</mn></msub><mtext>NH</mtext></math>, is a weak organic base. The reaction of <math alttext="C 5 H 10 N H, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>10</mn></msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> with <math alttext="H 2 O, liquid" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> is represented by the following equation. <math alttext="C 5 H 10 N H, aqueous, plus H 2 O, liquid, is in equilibrium with C 5 H 10 N H 2 with a positive 1 charge, aqueous, plus O H with a negative 1 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>10</mn></msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>10</mn></msub><msup><msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>+</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mtext>OH</mtext><mo>-</mo></msup><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> A. Identify one Brønsted-Lowry conjugate acid-base pair in the reaction of piperidine with water. Be sure to label which species is the acid and which is the base.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Piperidine, <math alttext="C 5 H 10 N H" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>10</mn></msub><mtext>NH</mtext></math>, is a weak organic base. The reaction of <math alttext="C 5 H 10 N H, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>10</mn></msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> with <math alttext="H 2 O, liquid" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> is represented by the following equation. <math alttext="C 5 H 10 N H, aqueous, plus H 2 O, liquid, is in equilibrium with C 5 H 10 N H 2 with a positive 1 charge, aqueous, plus O H with a negative 1 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>10</mn></msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>10</mn></msub><msup><msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>+</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mtext>OH</mtext><mo>-</mo></msup><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> A. Identify one Brønsted-Lowry conjugate acid-base pair in the reaction of piperidine with water. Be sure to label which species is the acid and which is the base.

B. Write the expression for the equilibrium constant, <math alttext="K b" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>b</mi></msub></math>, for piperidine, <math alttext="C 5 H 10 N H" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>10</mn></msub><mtext>NH</mtext></math>.

C. A <math alttext="20.0 milliliter" overflow="scroll"><mn>20.0</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>mL</mi></math> sample of <math alttext="0.750 molar C 5 H 10 N H, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.750</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>10</mn></msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is prepared at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mn>25</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></math>. i. The equilibrium concentration of <math alttext="O H with a negative 1 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>OH</mi><mo>-</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> in the solution is <math alttext="3.09 times 10 to the negative 2 power molar" overflow="scroll"><mn>3.09</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></math>. Calculate the <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mi>pH</mi></math> of the <math alttext="0.750 molar C 5 H 10 N H, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.750</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>10</mn></msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> solution at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mn>25</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></math>.
ii. What is the percent ionization of piperidine in the <math alttext="0.750 molar" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.750</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></math> solution?

D. When a small volume of strong acid is added to the <math alttext="0.750 molar C 5 H 10 N H, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.750</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>10</mn></msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> solution, the number of moles of <math alttext="C 5 H 10 N H 2 with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>10</mn></msub><msup><msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>+</mo></msup></math> increases. i. Write the balanced net ionic equation for the reaction that occurs between major species in solution when the strong acid is added.

ii. Using <math alttext="Q" overflow="scroll"><mi>Q</mi></math> and <math alttext="K" overflow="scroll"><mi>K</mi></math>, explain why the moles of <math alttext="C 5 H 10 N H 2 with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>10</mn></msub><msup><msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>+</mo></msup></math> increase when a small amount of strong acid is added to the solution.

A scientist prepares piperidine, <math alttext="C 5 H 10 N H" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>10</mn></msub><mtext>NH</mtext></math>, by reacting <math alttext="C 5 H 5 N" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><mtext>N</mtext></math> and <math alttext="H 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math> in a nickel-coated container at <math alttext="400, decimal point, kelvins" overflow="scroll"><mn>400.</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></math> according to the following reaction equation. <math alttext="C 5 H 5 N, gas, plus 3 H 2, gas, is in equilibrium with C 5 H 10 N H, gas. Delta G naught equals negative 42.8 kilojoules per mole of reaction." overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><mtext>N</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>10</mn></msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msup><mi>G</mi><mo>∘</mo></msup><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>42.8</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>kJ</mtext><mo>/</mo><msub><mtext>mol</mtext><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></math> The scientist fills a previously evacuated, sealed, rigid container with <math alttext="1.40 atmospheres" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.40</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>atm</mtext></math> of <math alttext="C 5 H 5 N" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><mtext>N</mtext></math> and <math alttext="1.40 atmospheres" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.40</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>atm</mtext></math> of <math alttext="H 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> and records the partial pressure of <math alttext="C 5 H 10 N H, gas" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>10</mn></msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> as the reaction progresses. The data are shown in the following graph. E. On the graph, sketch a single curve that represents the partial pressure of <math alttext="H 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> as the reaction proceeds from <math alttext="0" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn></math> minutes to <math alttext="30" overflow="scroll"><mn>30</mn></math> minutes. Your curve should reflect i. the rate of change of <math alttext="H 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> compared to that of <math alttext="C 5 H 10 N H, gas" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>10</mn></msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> and ii. the initial partial pressure of <math alttext="H 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi mathvariant="italic">g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> and the partial pressure of <math alttext="H 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi mathvariant="italic">g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> at <math alttext="30" overflow="scroll"><mn>30</mn></math> minutes.

F. In this reaction, <math alttext="4 moles" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mol</mtext></math> of gaseous reactants produce <math alttext="1 mole" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mol</mtext></math> of gaseous product. Based on this fact, a student claims that the entropy change of the forward reaction, <math alttext="delta S naught reaction" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msubsup><mi>S</mi><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow><mo>∘</mo></msubsup></math>, is negative. i. Use particulate-level reasoning to explain why the student’s claim is correct.

ii. Given the signs of <math alttext="delta G naught reaction" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msubsup><mi>G</mi><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow><mo>∘</mo></msubsup></math> and <math alttext="delta S naught reaction" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msubsup><mi>S</mi><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow><mo>∘</mo></msubsup></math> at <math alttext="400, decimal point, kelvins" overflow="scroll"><mn>400.</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></math>, is the sign of <math alttext="delta H naught reaction" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msubsup><mi>H</mi><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow><mo>∘</mo></msubsup></math> positive or negative? Justify your answer.

skill.text: 1.A: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate particulate-level properties only.
